docs.title: How do I use this wiki?
docs.text:
All the categories are visible on the top navbar. All the topics are visible on the left sidebar (in the left drawer on mobile). All the page content headings are visible on the right sidebar (in the left drawer on mobile).

You can use the search bar to navigate around easily. Feel free to ask on our Discord server if it's nowhere to be found.

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Discord
  • GitHub

docs.title: Setting up from source
docs.text: In order to set up or build the source code some of the projects from the yukino repository, additional beforehand setup is required.

docs.title: Kazahana
docs.text:
Requirements: - Flutter SDK - Android SDK - (Optional)Git

In your browser, navigate to the Kazahana Repository and press the green code button and download the zip.

Once you have the source downloaded and opened in visual studio code, run flutter pub get. Next, run flutter packages pub run build_runner build --delete-conflicting-outputs You should now be set to begin developing or building from source.

For any additional information on contributing or the custom dependencies used within Kazahana, please check their corresponding tabs.

docs.title: Contribution
docs.text: Yukino Org follows certain guidelines to maintain code integrity and uniformity. It is required to follow these guidelines in order for you to contribute.

docs.title: Before-hand
docs.text:
• I appreciate any contributions to any of the repository and every single feedback. And don't feel bad if your issue or pull request was closed. 🙂
  • Always check if it the right repository before opening an issue or a pull request.
  • Check if there is a similar issue or a pull request before committing.
  • Refer similar or other issues or pull requests if it's your first time.

docs.title: Guidelines
docs.text:
• Always follow the same conventions used in the project. (Example: Using snake_case when necessary, organizing files according to their use)
  • Always follow Conventional Commits.
  • Always document the changes you have made.
  • Always follow same versioning of the corresponding project. (Example: SemVer)
  • An issue or a pull request must be related to only one topic. Do not make a pull request containing multiple feature or bug fixes.
  • Always ask for reviews before asking to merge a pull request.
  • Always try to use the pre-defined templates for issues and pull requests. Make sure to fill it completely. Invalid issues or pull requests will be closed.
  • Keep it as professional as possible.

Warning

Opening issues in wrong repository will result in the issue being marked as invalid or will be moved to the corresponding repository.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The language syntax is a mix of Go and JavaScript. It is also highly dynamic with only basic features. Fubuki script files takes an extension of .fbs. The program can be compiled using Fubuki Compiler and can be run on Fubuki VM.

Info

  • Optional things are mentioned within brackets ([]). Escaped brackets (\[\]) says that they are part of the syntax itself.

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
Words in a line after # are comments. Multi-line comments are not supported.

# This is a comment.

docs.title: Keywords
docs.text:
true
false
null
if
else
while
fun
return
break
continue
obj
try
catch
throw
import
as
list
map
when
match

docs.title: Identifiers
docs.text:
Identifiers are made up of alphabets (A-Z, a-z), dollar sign ($) and underscore (_). Numbers (0-9) can also be used but are not allowed at the start of an identifier. Keywords cannot be used as identifiers.

Fubuki does not have a standard naming convention but camel-case is preferred.

helloWorld
HelloWorld
_helloWorld
$HELLO_WORLD
hello_world
$hello123

docs.title: Expressions
docs.text:
Expression is a piece of code that is evaluated to a value. Literals, operations using operators, identifiers come under expressions.

helloWorld
1 + 2
"Hello World!"

Info

Trailing commas are allowed in function parameters, function call, object key-value pairs and list values. For example, [1, 2, 3,] is perfectly valid and same as [1, 2, 3].

docs.title: Statements
docs.text: Statements is a line of code that commands a task. Each program is made up of sequence of statements. Statements must end with a semi-colon (;).

docs.title: Hello World!
docs.text: print "Hello World!";

docs.title: Area of shapes
docs.text:
square := {
    area: -> side : side * side,
};

rectangle := {
    area: -> length, breadth : length * breadth,
};

print "Area of square: " + square.area(5);
print "Area of rectangle: " + rectangle.area(2, 3);

docs.title: Print until 100 and as a list
docs.text:
i := 0;
numbers := [];
while (i <= 100) {
    print i;
    numbers.add(i);
    i = i + 1;
}
print numbers;

docs.title: Boolean
docs.text:
Represents truthiness using true or false.

Syntax
true
false

docs.title: Function
docs.text:
Represents a callable object. Functions are prefixed with right arrow operator (->). They are anonymous and cannot have a named unlike other programming languages. They are invoked using call operator. They can take in parameters and may return values.

Syntax
-> [param1, param2, ..., paramN] {
    statements
}

-> [param1, param2, ..., paramN] : expr
Example
-> { return 1; }
-> a, b { return a + b; }

-> a, b : a + b
-> x : x

docs.title: call
docs.text:
Calls the function and returns the result.

Signature
(params: List<Any>) => Any

docs.title: List
docs.text:
Represents a list of values.

Syntax
\[[expr1, expr2, ..., exprN]\]
Example
[]
[1, 2, 3]

docs.title: push
docs.text:
Adds value to the list.

Signature
(value: Any) => Null

docs.title: pushAll
docs.text:
Adds all values of values to the list.

Signature
(values: List<Any>) => Null

docs.title: pop
docs.text:
Removes the last element.

Signature
() => Null

docs.title: clear
docs.text:
Removes all the elements.

Signature
() => Null

docs.title: length
docs.text:
Returns length of the list.

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: isEmpty
docs.text:
Is the list empty?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: isNotEmpty
docs.text:
Is the list not empty?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: clone
docs.text:
Returns clone of the list.

Signature
() => List<Any>

docs.title: reversed
docs.text:
Returns reversed clone of the list.

Signature
() => List<Any>

docs.title: contains
docs.text:
Check if element is present in the list.

Signature
(element: Any) => Boolean

docs.title: indexOf
docs.text:
Returns the index of element in the list.

Signature
(element: Any) => Boolean

docs.title: lastIndexOf
docs.text:
Returns the last index of element in the list.

Signature
(element: Any) => Boolean

docs.title: remove
docs.text:
Removes all element from the list.

Signature
(element: Any) => Boolean

docs.title: sublist
docs.text:
Returns a sub-list consisting elements between start and end.

Signature
(start: Number, end: Number) => List<Any>

docs.title: find
docs.text:
Returns the matched element using the predicate.

Signature
(predicate: (element: Any) => Boolean) => Any

docs.title: findIndex
docs.text:
Returns the index of matched element using the predicate.

Signature
(predicate: (element: Any) => Boolean) => Number

docs.title: findLastIndex
docs.text:
Returns the last index of matched element using the predicate.

Signature
(predicate: (element: Any) => Boolean) => Number

docs.title: map
docs.text:
Returns the list of mapped values using predicate.

Signature
(predicate: (element: Any) => Any) => List<Any>

docs.title: filter
docs.text:
Returns the list of filtered values using predicate.

Signature
(predicate: (element: Any) => Boolean) => List<Any>

docs.title: sort
docs.text:
Returns the sorted list of using sortBy.

Signature
(sortBy: (a: Any, b: Any) => Number) => List<Any>

docs.title: flat
docs.text:
Returns the flatted list of level level.

Signature
(level: Number) => List<Any>

docs.title: flatDeep
docs.text:
Returns the flatted list of level this.length.

Signature
() => List<Any>

docs.title: unique
docs.text:
Returns the list of unique elements.

Signature
() => List<Any>

docs.title: forEach
docs.text:
Iterates the list using predicate.

Signature
(predicate: (element: Any) => Null) => Null

docs.title: join
docs.text:
Returns the elements converted to string, joined by delimiter.

Signature
(delimiter: String) => String

docs.title: Null
docs.text:
Represents a null value. Also can be called as void or nothing.

Syntax
null
Example
null

docs.title: Number
docs.text:
Represents a double-precision floating point value. Supports exponents (XeY) and hexadecimal (0xAAAAAAAA) values. NaN is used to denote a invalid number. Infinity, negative infinity and NaN can be created using native number helpers.

Syntax (RegExp)
-?\d+(\.\d+)?
-?\d+(\.\d+)?e(\+|-)?\d+
-?0[Xx][A-Fa-f]+
Example
0
-140
-9.2
100
250.67
10e2
10e-4
0xfff

docs.title: sign
docs.text:
Returns the -1 (less than zero), 0 (zero) or 1 (greater than zero).

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: isFinite
docs.text:
Is the number finite?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: isInfinite
docs.text:
Is the number infinite?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: isNaN
docs.text:
Is the number NaN?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: isNegative
docs.text:
Is the number negative?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: abs
docs.text:
Returns the number without sign.

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: ceil
docs.text:
Returns the number rounded towards positive infinity.

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: round
docs.text:
Returns the number rounded towards negative infinity.

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: truncate
docs.text:
Returns the number discarding fractional digits.

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: precisionString
docs.text:
Returns the number string with specified precision.

Signature
(digits: Number) => String

docs.title: Object
docs.text:
Represents a pair of keys and values. Objects are not created from classes since classes do not even exist. The keys are parsed as identifiers and values are parsed as expressions. Any keys using surrounding brackets ([]) are parsed as expressions. They properties can be accessed using the get and set operators.

Syntax
{
    [property: expr,]
    ...
    [\[expr\]: expr,]
    ...
}
Example
{}

{
    hello1: "world1",
    ["hello2"]: "world2",
    [1]: "world3",
}

docs.title: String
docs.text:
Represents a string value. Strings can be prefixed with r to parse them as they are. Strings are always multi-line.

Syntax (RegExp)
'[\S\s]*'
"[\S\s]*"
r'[\S\s]*'
r"[\S\s]*"
Example
'Hello'
"Hello"
r'This is a raw string'
r"This is a raw string"
'Supports escape sequences like \t \n'
"but also unicodes like \u0041 and \x41"

'Easy
and
peasy'

docs.title: isEmpty
docs.text:
Is string empty?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: isNotEmpty
docs.text:
Is string not empty?

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: length
docs.text:
Length of the string.

Signature
() => Number

docs.title: compareTo
docs.text:
Compare to another string. Returns 0 if equal.

Signature
(other: String) => Number

docs.title: contains
docs.text:
Check if other is present in the string.

Signature
(other: String) => Boolean

docs.title: startsWith
docs.text:
Check if the string is prefixed with other.

Signature
(other: String) => Boolean

docs.title: endsWith
docs.text:
Check if the string is suffixed with other.

Signature
(other: String) => Boolean

docs.title: indexOf
docs.text:
Position of substring in the string. Returns -1 if not present.

Signature
(substring: String) => Number

docs.title: substring
docs.text:
Returns a substring between start and end.

Signature
(start: Number, end: Number) => String

docs.title: replaceFirst
docs.text:
Replaces first substring with with.

Signature
(pattern: String, with: String) => String

docs.title: replaceAll
docs.text:
Replaces all substring with with.

Signature
(pattern: String, with: String) => String

docs.title: replaceFirstMapped
docs.text:
Replaces first substring with value returned by with.

Signature
(pattern: String, mapper: (String) => String) => String

docs.title: replaceAllMapped
docs.text:
Replaces all substring with value returned by with.

Signature
(pattern: String, mapper: (String) => String) => String

docs.title: trim
docs.text:
Removes all whitespaces at the ends.

Signature
() => String

docs.title: trimLeft
docs.text:
Removes all whitespaces at the start.

Signature
() => String

docs.title: trimRight
docs.text:
Removes all whitespaces at the end.

Signature
() => String

docs.title: padLeft
docs.text:
Pads using with at the start.

Signature
(length: Number, with: String) => String

docs.title: padRight
docs.text:
Pads using with at the end.

Signature
(length: Number, with: String) => String

docs.title: split
docs.text:
Splits the string at splitters.

Signature
(splitter: String) => List<String>

docs.title: codeUnitAt
docs.text:
Returns code-unit at index.

Signature
(index: Number) => String

docs.title: toCodeUnits
docs.text:
Returns code-units of the string.

Signature
() => List<Number>

docs.title: toLowerCase
docs.text:
Returns the string in lowercase.

Signature
() => String

docs.title: toUpperCase
docs.text:
Returns the string in uppercase.

Signature
() => String

docs.title: format
docs.text:
Returns the formatted string. Example: "{} {1}".format(["Hello", "World"]), "{hello} {world}".format({ hello: "Hello", world: "World" }) returns Hello World

Signature
(env: Object | List<Any>) => String

docs.title: Boolean.from
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns the boolean equivalent.

Boolean.from(0);
# false

Boolean.from(1);
# false

Boolean.from(null);
# false

docs.title: BytesList
docs.text:
An internally represented bytes list.

Property Signature Description bytes () => List<Number> Returns the bytes as a list.

docs.title: Convert.newBytesList
docs.text:
Takes in an optional byte list and returns a BytesList.

bytes := Convert.newBytesList();
# internally, []

bytes = Convert.newBytesList([0, 1, 2]);
# internally, [0, 1, 2]

bytes.bytes();
# returns the internal list, [0, 1, 2]

docs.title: Convert.encodeAscii
docs.text:
Takes in a string and returns a BytesList.

Convert.encodeAscii("Hello");
# internally, [72, 101, 108, 108, 111]

docs.title: Convert.decodeAscii
docs.text:
Takes in a BytesList and returns a string.

bytes := Convert.newBytesList([72, 101, 108, 108, 111]);
Convert.decodeAscii(bytes);
# Hello

docs.title: Convert.encodeBase64
docs.text:
Takes in a BytesList and returns a base64 string.

bytes := Convert.newBytesList([72, 101, 108, 108, 111]);
Convert.encodeBase64(bytes);
# SGVsbG8=

docs.title: Convert.decodeBase64
docs.text:
Takes in a base64 string and returns a BytesList.

Convert.decodeBase64("SGVsbG8=");
# internally, [72, 101, 108, 108, 111]

docs.title: Convert.encodeLatin1
docs.text:
Takes in a string and returns a BytesList.

Convert.encodeLatin1("Hello");
# internally, [72, 101, 108, 108, 111]

docs.title: Convert.decodeLatin1
docs.text:
Takes in a BytesList and returns a string.

bytes := Convert.newBytesList([72, 101, 108, 108, 111]);
Convert.decodeLatin1(bytes);
# Hello

docs.title: Convert.encodeUtf8
docs.text:
Takes in a string and returns a BytesList.

Convert.encodeUtf8("Hello");
# internally, [72, 101, 108, 108, 111]

docs.title: Convert.decodeUtf8
docs.text:
Takes in a BytesList and returns a string.

bytes := Convert.newBytesList([72, 101, 108, 108, 111]);
Convert.decodeUtf8(bytes);
# Hello

docs.title: Convert.encodeJson
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns json string.

json := {
    hello: "world",
};
Convert.encodeJson(json);
# {"hello":"world"}

docs.title: Convert.decodeJson
docs.text:
Takes in a json string and returns a value.

json := '{"hello":"world"}';
Convert.decodeJson(json);
# { hello: "world" }

docs.title: DateTimeInst
docs.text:
Contains information about the time.

Property Signature Description day Number Date of the month. [1..31] weekday Number Day of the week. [1..7] (1 - Monday, ..., 7 - Sunday) month Number Month of the year. [1..12] year Number Year. hour Number Hour of the day. [0..23] minute Number Minute of the hour. [0..59] second Number Second of the minute. [0..59] millisecond Number Milliseconds of the second. [0..999] millisecondsSinceEpoch Number Number of milliseconds since the Unix Epoch. timeZoneName String Name of the time zone. timeZoneOffset Number Difference between local time and UTC in milliseconds. iso String ISO-8601 full-precision extended format representation.

docs.title: DateTime.fromMillisecondsSinceEpoch
docs.text:
Takes in an number (milliseconds since epoch) and returns a DateTimeInst.

ms := 1673540148833;
DateTime.fromMillisecondsSinceEpoch(ms);

docs.title: DateTime.parse
docs.text:
Takes in a ISO string, date string, time string or any parsable date-time value and returns a DateTimeInst.

DateTime.parse("20/10/2023");

docs.title: DateTime.now
docs.text:
Returns a DateTimeInst of current time.

DateTime.now();

docs.title: ExceptionInst
docs.text:
Contains information about an exception.

Property Signature message String stackTrace String

docs.title: Exception.new
docs.text:
Takes in a message, optional stack trace and returns a ExceptionInst.

Exception.new("Something went wrong!");
# Exception: Something went wrong!
# Stack Trace:
# ...

Exception.new("Something went wrong!", "at line 1");
# Exception: Something went wrong!
# Stack Trace:
# at line 1

docs.title: Fiber.wait
docs.text:
Takes in duration in milliseconds and returns a future that resolved after the duration.

Future.wait(1000);
# waits 1 second

docs.title: Fiber.runConcurrently
docs.text:
Takes in a list of functions that returns the list of values returned.

Fiber.runConcurrently([-> : result1, -> : result2, ..., -> : resultN]);

docs.title: Function.call
docs.text:
Takes in an function, list of arguments and returns the result of the function after calling.

Function.call(someFunction, [a, b, c]);

docs.title: typeof
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns the type. The type will be any one of Boolean, Function, NativeFunction, AsyncNativeFunction, Null, Number, String, Object, List or Future.

typeof(10);
# Number

typeof("Hello");
# String

docs.title: List.from
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns a list. If the value is a list, the list is cloned. If the value is a map, the entries are returned. An exception is thrown if it is neither of these.

List.from([0, 1, 2]);
# [0, 1, 2]

List.from({ hello: "world" });
# [["hello", "world"]]

docs.title: List.generate
docs.text:
Takes in a length, a predicate that returns a value and returns the generated list.

List.from(3, -> i : i + 1);
# [1, 2, 3]

docs.title: List.filled
docs.text:
Takes in a length, a value and returns the list.

List.from(3, 10);
# [10, 10, 10]

docs.title: Number.infinity
docs.text:
Returns infinity.

Number.infinity
# Infinity

docs.title: Number.negativeInfinity
docs.text:
Returns negative infinity.

Number.negativeInfinity
# -Infinity

docs.title: Number.NaN
docs.text:
Returns NaN.

Number.NaN
# NaN

docs.title: Number.maxFinite
docs.text:
Returns the maximum value of number.

Number.maxFinite
# 1.7976931348623157e+308

docs.title: Number.from
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns a number.

Number.from("10");
# 10

Number.from(11);
# 10

docs.title: Number.fromOrNull
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns a number or null.

Number.from("10");
# 10

Number.from([]);
# null

docs.title: Object.from
docs.text:
Takes in an object and returns the clone of it.

Object.from({});
# {}

Object.from({ hello: "world" });
# { hello: "world" }

docs.title: Object.fromEntries
docs.text:
Takes in an list of entries and returns an object.

Object.fromEntries([]);
# {}

Object.fromEntries([["hello", "world"]]);
# { hello: "world" }

docs.title: Object.apply
docs.text:
Takes in two objects and returns object A after applying properties of object B to object A.

a := {};
b := {
    hello: "world",
};

Object.apply(a, b);

print a;
# { hello: "world" }

docs.title: Object.entries
docs.text:
Takes in an object and returns a list of key-value pairs in a list.

Object.entries({ hello: "world", foo: "bar" });
# [["hello", "world"], ["foo", "bar"]]

docs.title: Object.keys
docs.text:
Takes in an object and returns a list of keys.

Object.keys({ hello: "world", foo: "bar" });
# ["hello", "foo"]

docs.title: Object.values
docs.text:
Takes in an object and returns a list of values.

Object.values({ hello: "world", foo: "bar" });
# ["world", "bar"]

docs.title: Object.clone
docs.text:
Takes in an object and returns a clone of it.

Object.clone({ hello: "world" });
# { hello: "world" }

docs.title: Object.deleteProperty
docs.text:
Takes in an object, a key and removes the key from the object.

value := { hello: "world", foo: "bar" };
Object.deleteProperty(value, "hello");
print value;
# { foo: "bar" }

docs.title: RegExp
docs.text:
The regular expression.

Property Signature Description isCaseInsensitive Boolean Is case insensitive flag enabled? isDotAll Boolean Is dot-all flag enabled? isMultiline Boolean Is multiline flag enabled? isUnicode Boolean Is unicode flag enabled? pattern String Regular expression pattern. hasMatch (input: String) => Boolean Does input has matches against the pattern. stringMatch (input: String) => String Returns the string match of input against the pattern. firstMatch (input: String) => RegExpMatch? Returns the match of input against the pattern. allMatches (input: String) => List<RegExpMatch> Returns the all the matches of input against the pattern. replaceFirst (input: String, with: String) => String Returns a string after replacing first match of input against the pattern using with. replaceAll (input: String, with: String) => String Returns a string after replacing all the matches of input against the pattern using with. replaceFirstMapped (input: String, with: (RegExpMatch) => String) => String Returns a string after replacing first match of input against the pattern using the value returned by with. replaceAllMapped (input: String, with: (RegExpMatch) => String) => String Returns a string after replacing all the matches of input against the pattern using the value returned by with.

docs.title: RegExpMatch
docs.text:
Contains information about a regular expression match.

Property Signature Description input String The input. groupCount Number The number of groups. groupNames List<String> The names of the groups. namedGroup (groupName: String) => RegExpMatch? Returns the match using the groupName. group (index: Number) => RegExpMatch? Returns the match at the index.

docs.title: RegExp.new
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns the boolean equivalent.

RegExp.new(r"\w+");
# regexp of pattern \w+

RegExp.new("\\d+");
# regexp of pattern \d+

docs.title: String.from
docs.text:
Takes in a value and returns a string.

String.from(false);
# "false"

String.from(1);
# "1"

String.from([1, 2, 3]);
# "[1, 2, 3]"

docs.title: String.fromCodeUnit
docs.text:
Takes in a byte and returns the equivalent character value as string.

String.fromCodeUnit(72);
# H

docs.title: String.fromCodeUnits
docs.text:
Takes in a byte and returns the equivalent character value as string.

String.fromCodeUnit([72, 101, 108, 108, 111]);
# Hello

docs.title: Addition
docs.text:
Addition operator (=) can be used to add two numbers or concate two strings.

Syntax
operand1 + operand2
Example
3 + 2
# 5

"Hello" + " World"
# Hello World

"Hello " + 1
# Hello1

docs.title: Assignment
docs.text:
Assignment operator (=) can be used to set a new value to a variable.

Syntax
variable = expr
Example
a = 3
b = 4

docs.title: Bitwise AND
docs.text:
Bitwise AND operator (&) can be used to perform binary AND operation on two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 & operand2
Example
a & b

1 & 1
# 1

2 & 4
# 0

4 & 4
# 4

docs.title: Bitwise NOT
docs.text:
Bitwise NOT operator (~) can be used to perform binary NOT operation on numbers.

Syntax
-operand1
Example
~2
~someNumberValue

docs.title: Bitwise OR
docs.text:
Bitwise OR operator (|) can be used to perform binary OR operation on two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 | operand2
Example
a | b

1 | 1
# 1

2 | 4
# 6

docs.title: Bitwise XOR
docs.text:
Bitwise XOR operator (^) can be used to perform binary XOR operation on two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 ^ operand2
Example
a ^ b

1 ^ 0
# 1

1 ^ 1
# 0

4 ^ 2
# 6

docs.title: Call
docs.text:
Call operator (()) is used to invoke a function. They may take in parameters.

Syntax
operand1([param1, param2, ..., param3])
Example
someFunctionValue()
someFunctionValue(a, b, c)
main()
display(a, b, c)

docs.title: Computed Member Access
docs.text:
Member Access operator (.) can be used to access properties of an object but they accessor is an expression.

Syntax
object[expr]
Example
someObjectValue['propertyA']
someObjectValue['propertyA']['propertyB']

docs.title: Declaration
docs.text:
Declaration operator (:=) is used to declare a variable in the enclosing lexical scope. Variables cannot be re-declared.

Syntax
variable := expr
Example
a := 2
b := 3

docs.title: Division
docs.text:
Division operator (/) can be used to divide two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 / operand2
Example
10 / 3
# 3.333

docs.title: Equality
docs.text:
Equality operator (==) can be used to find if two values are equal.

Syntax
operand1 == operand2
Example
a == b

1 == 2
# false

"Hello" == "Hello"
# true

"Hello" == "World"
# false

docs.title: Exponent
docs.text:
Exponent operator (**) can be used to calculate exponentiation result of two number.

Syntax
operand1 ** operand2
Example
2 ** 3
# 8

docs.title: Floor Division
docs.text:
Floor Division operator (//) can be used to floor divide two numbers. This performs floor on the result after division.

Syntax
operand1 // operand2
Example
10 // 3
# 3

docs.title: Greater Than Or Equal
docs.text:
Greater Than Or Equal (>=) can be used to find if a is greater than or equal to b.

Syntax
operand1 >= operand2
Example
a >= b

1 >= 2
# false

3 >= 3
# true

4 >= 3
# true

docs.title: Greater Than
docs.text:
Greater Than (>) can be used to find if a is greater than b.

Syntax
operand1 > operand2
Example
a > b

1 > 2
# false

4 > 2
# true

docs.title: Grouping
docs.text:
Expressions surrounded by parenthesis (()) are evaluated first.

Syntax
(expr)
Example
1 - (2 + 4)
# -5

docs.title: Inequality
docs.text:
Inequality operator (!=) can be used to find if two values are not equal.

Syntax
operand1 != operand2
Example
a != b

1 != 2
# true

"Hello" != "Hello"
# false

"Hello" != "World"
# true

docs.title: Lesser Than Or Equal
docs.text:
Lesser Than Or Equal (<=) can be used to find if a is lesser than or equal to b.

Syntax
operand1 <= operand2
Example
a <= b

1 <= 2
# true

3 <= 3
# true

4 <= 3
# false

docs.title: Lesser Than
docs.text:
Lesser Than (<) can be used to find if a is lesser than b.

Syntax
operand1 < operand2
Example
a < b

1 < 2
# true

4 < 2
# false

docs.title: Logical AND
docs.text:
Logical AND operator (&&) returns true if both values are true.

Syntax
operand1 && operand2
Example
a && b

true && true
# true

true && false
# false

docs.title: Logical NOT
docs.text:
Logical NOT operator (!) can be used to invert boolean or truthy value. This always returns a boolean value.

Syntax
!operand1
Example
!true
# false

!false
# true

!someBooleanValue
!someValue
!!someValue

docs.title: Logical OR
docs.text:
Logical OR operator (||) returns true if atleast one of two values is true.

Syntax
operand1 || operand2
Example
a || b

true || false
# true

false || false
# false

docs.title: Member Access
docs.text:
Member Access operator (.) can be used to access properties of an object.

Syntax
object.property
Example
someObjectValue.propertyA
someObjectValue.propertyA.propertyB

docs.title: Multiplication
docs.text:
Multiplication operator (*) can be used to multiply two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 * operand2
Example
9 * 2
# 18

docs.title: Nullable Access
docs.text:
Nullable Access operator (?.) can be used to access properties of an object or null. This returns null, if the accessor is on a null value.

Syntax
value?.property
Example
someObjectValueOrNull?.propertyA
someObjectValueOrNull?.propertyA.propertyB

# can also be used with computed member access
someObjectValueOrNull?.['propertyA']

# can also be used with calls
someFunctionValueOrNull?.()

docs.title: Nullable OR
docs.text:
Nullable OR operator (??) can be used to return a alternative value when the primary value is null, i.e. returns right-hand side value if left-hand side value is null.

Syntax
expr1 ?? expr2
Example
a ?? b

null ?? 2
# 2

1 ?? 2
# 1

docs.title: Precedence Table
docs.text: Name Operator Precedence Default - 0 Declaration … := … 1 Assignment … = … 1 Ternary … ? … : … 1 Logical OR … \|\| … 2 Nullable OR … ?? … 2 Logical AND … && … 3 Bitwise OR … \| … 4 Bitwise XOR … ^ … 5 Bitwise AND … & … 6 Equality … == … 7 Inequality … != … 7 Lesser Than … < … 8 Lesser Than Or Equal … <= … 8 Greater Than … > … 8 Greater Than Or Equal … >= … 8 Addition … + … 9 Subtraction … - … 9 Multiplication … * … 10 Division … / … 10 Floor Division … // … 10 Remainder … % … 10 Exponent … ** … 11 Logical NOT ! … 12 Bitwise NOT ~ … 12 Unary Plus + … 12 Unary Negation - … 12 Call … () 13 Member Access … . … 13 Computed Member Access … [ … ] 13 Nullable Access … ?. … 13 Grouping ( … ) 14

docs.title: Remainder
docs.text:
Remainder operator (%) can be used to get remainder from division of two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 % operand2
Example
11 % 2
# 1

docs.title: Subtraction
docs.text:
Subtraction operator (-) can be used to subtract two numbers.

Syntax
operand1 - operand2
Example
5 - 2
# 3

docs.title: Ternary Operator
docs.text:
Ternary operator (?:) has a condition and two values that is evaluated as per the truthiness of the condition.

Syntax
condition ? trueExpr : falseExpr
Example
1 > 2 ? "Yes!" : "No!"
# No!

4 < 2 ? 2 : 4
# 4

docs.title: Unary negation
docs.text:
Unary negation operator (-) can be used to represent a negative number or to invert the sign of a number.

Syntax
+operand1
Example
-50
-12.1
-0
-someNumberValue

docs.title: Unary Plus
docs.text:
Unary plus operator (+) can be used to represent a positive number.

Syntax
+operand1
Example
+20
+45.6
+0
+someNumberValue

docs.title: Block Statement
docs.text:
Creates a lexical scope and contains a sequence of statements.

Syntax
{
    statement1;
    statement2;
    ...
    statementN;
}
Example
{
    a := 2;
    print a;
}

docs.title: Break Statement
docs.text:
Break statement can be used to terminate the enclosing loop. This is done using the break keyword.

Syntax
break;
Example
i := 0;
while (true) {
    print i;
    i = i + 1;
    if (i > 2) break;
}
# 0 1 2

docs.title: Continue Statement
docs.text:
Continue statement can be used to skip current iteration. This is done using the continue keyword.

Syntax
continue;
Example
i := 0;
while (i < 6) {
    i = i + 1;
    if (i % 2 == 0) continue;
    print i;
}
# 1 3 5

docs.title: Expression Statement
docs.text:
Contains nothing but an expression.

Syntax
expr;
Example
1 + 1;
"Hello World";
helloWorld;

docs.title: If-Else Statement
docs.text:
If-else statement is a conditional control-flow statement that allows skipping code. Supports simple if, if-else and if-else ladder.

Syntax
if (condition)
    statement1

if (condition)
    statement1
else
    statement2

if (condition1)
    statement1
else if (condition2)
    statement2
else
    statement3
Example
if (true) print "Hello World";

if (false) print "Hello World";
else print "Goodbye World";

text := ""
if (true) {
    text = "Hello World";
} else {
    text = "Goodbye World";
}
print text;

docs.title: Import Statements
docs.text:
Import statements are used to import other modules into current module. The top-most lexical scope of the module is mirrored.

Syntax
import "filename" as variable;
Example
import "utils.fbs" as utils;

print utils.helloWorld;
utils.displayHelloWorld();

docs.title: Match Statement
docs.text:
Match statements can be used to match values against the case values. Each case takes in an expression that evaluates to a value, and is executed if they are equal. The else case is invoked if none matches. Atmost one case is executed.

Syntax
match (expr) {
    expr1: statement1
    expr2: statement2
    ...
    exprN: statementN
    else: elseStatement
}
Example
a := 0
match (a) {
    -1: {
        print "Found: -1";
    }
    0: print "Found: 0";
    1: print "Found: 1";
    else: print a;
}
# Found: 0

docs.title: Print Statement
docs.text:
Print statement is used to print a value to the terminal. This is done using the print keyword. This statement cannot be used if disablePrint is set to true.

Syntax
print expr;
Example
print 1;
print "Hello World";

docs.title: Return Statement
docs.text:
Return statement is used to return a value from the function body to it's call. This is done using the return keyword. If no value is specified, null value is returned.

Syntax
return;
return expr;
Example
return;
return null;
return "Hello World";

docs.title: Throw Statement
docs.text:
Throw statements can be used to propogate exceptions. This is done using the throw keyword.

Syntax
throw expr;
Example
throw "Hello World!";
throw Exception.new("Oops!");

docs.title: Try-Catch Statement
docs.text:
Try-catch statement is used to handle exceptions and unintended behaviours. Try-catch consists a try block that might throw exceptions and catch block that handles the exception.

Syntax
try {
    tryStatements
} catch (exception) {
    catchStatements
}
Example
try {
    throw "Hello World!";
} catch (err) {
    print err;
}
# Hello World!

docs.title: When Statement
docs.text:
When statements can be used as an alternative to if-else ladder. Each case takes in an conditional expression, and is executed if they are truthy. The else case is invoked if none evaluates to a truthy value. Atmost one case is executed.

Syntax
when {
    expr1: statement1
    expr2: statement2
    ...
    exprN: statementN
    else: elseStatement
}
Example
a := 2
b := 3
when {
    a > b: {
        print "Yes";
    }
    else: print "No";
}
# No

docs.title: While Statement
docs.text:
While statements allows repeating a set of code until the condition goes falsey. break and continue statement can be used inside a loop.

Syntax
while (condition) {
    statement
}
Example
i := 0;
while (i < 5) {
    print i;
    i = i + 1;
}
# 0 1 2 3 4

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text:
• The information provided by this project is solely for personal use only.
  • The core aim of this project is to efficiently parse sites without any advertisements.
  • The content served by the modules has no control.
  • The developer of this organization does not take any responsibility for the content displayed by the modules and is not affliated with them by any means.
  • Most of the contents served by the module are from public websites that are accessible by anyone through a browser.
  • Any DMCA or copyright infrigment must be forwarded to the website and not to the developer.
  • This project must be used at the risk of the user based on their government laws.

docs.title: Module Structure
docs.text: The fubuki script must contain a variable extractor that is either a AnimeExtractor or MangaExtractor in its entrypoint file.

docs.title: AnimeExtractor
docs.text:
Signature
{
    defaultLocale: String,
    search: (terms: String, locale: String) => List<SearchInfo>,
    getInfo: (url: String, locale: String) => AnimeInfo,
    getSources: (url: String, locale: String) => List<EpisodeSource>,
}

docs.title: MangaExtractor
docs.text:
Signature
{
    defaultLocale: String,
    search: (terms: String, locale: String) => List<SearchInfo>,
    getInfo: (url: String, locale: String) => MangaInfo,
    getChapter: (url: String, locale: String) => List<PageInfo>,
    getPage: (url: String, locale: String) => ImageDescriber,
}

docs.title: SearchInfo
docs.text:
Signature
{
    title: String,
    url: String,
    locale: String,
    thumbnail: ImageDescriber?,
}

docs.title: AnimeInfo
docs.text:
Signature
{
    title: String,
    url: String,
    episodes: List<EpisodeInfo>,
    locale: String,
    availableLocales: String,
    thumbnail: ImageDescriber?,
}

docs.title: MangaInfo
docs.text:
Signature
{
    title: String,
    url: String,
    chapters: List<ChapterInfo>,
    locale: String,
    availableLocales: String,
    thumbnail: ImageDescriber?,
}

docs.title: EpisodeInfo
EpisodeSource
docs.text:
Signature
{
    url: String,
    quality: "144p" | "360p" | "480p" | "720p" | "1080p"
        | "144" | "360" | "480" | "720" | "1080" | "unknown"
        | "sd" | "hd" | "fhd" | "?",
    headers: Object,
    locale: String,
}

docs.title: ChapterInfo
docs.text:
Signature
{
    chapter: String,
    url: String,
    locale: String,
    title: String?,
    volume: String?,
}

docs.title: PageInfo
ImageDescriber
Configuration
docs.text:
# name of the extension
name: some-site.com

# repository details
repo:
username: your-github-username
repo: your-github-repo-name
ref: sha-of-the-commit

# source code's path
source:
root: path/to/directory
file: filename.fbs

# thumbnail's path (Resolution must be 96x96 and a png)
thumbnail: path/to/logo.png

# could contain nsfw content
nsfw: false

More examples can be viewed here.

docs.title: Crypto.md5Convert
docs.text:
Digest as md5.

Signature
(input: BytesList) => BytesList

docs.title: Crypto.aesEncrypt
docs.text:
Encryption based upon AES.

Signature
(options: {
    input: BytesList,
    key: BytesList,
    iv: BytesList?,
    mode: "cbc" | "cfb64" | "ctr" | "ecb" | "ofb64Gctr" | "ofb64" | "sic",
    padding: "PKCS7" | String,
}) => BytesList

docs.title: Crypto.aesDecrypt
docs.text:
Decryption based upon AES.

Signature
(options: {
    input: BytesList,
    key: BytesList,
    iv: BytesList?,
    mode: "cbc" | "cfb64" | "ctr" | "ecb" | "ofb64Gctr" | "ofb64" | "sic",
    padding: "PKCS7" | String,
}) => BytesList

docs.title: FuzzySearchClient
docs.text:
Represents the fuzzy search client.

Property Signature Description search (terms: String) => List<FuzzyResult> Returns the search results.

docs.title: FuzzyResult
docs.text:
Represents the result of fuzzy search.

Property Signature Description match Number Match ratio. item Any The item.

docs.title: FuzzySearch.new
docs.text:
Digest as md5.

Signature
({
    items: List<Any>,
    keys: List<{
        getter: (item: Any) => Any,
        weight: Number,
    }>,
}) => FuzzySearchClient

docs.title: HtmlElementInst
docs.text:
Represents a HTML element.

Property Signature Description classes List<String> The element's class list. id String The element id. text String The element text. innerHtml String The element inner HTML. outerHtml String The element outer HTML. attributes Object The element's attributes. querySelector (selector: String) => HtmlElementInst Returns the selected element. querySelectorAll (selector: String) => List<HtmlElementInst> Returns all the selected elements.

docs.title: HtmlElement.parse
docs.text:
Parses the HTML text.

Signature
(html: String) => HtmlElementInst

docs.title: HttpResponse
docs.text:
Represents a http response.

Property Signature Description body String The response body. headers Object The response headers. statusCode String The response status code. reasonPhrase String The response reason phrase. isRedirect Boolean Is it a redirect?

docs.title: Http.request
docs.text:
Fetches a URL and returns the result.

Signature
(options: {
    method: "get" | "post" | "head" | "patch" | "delete" | "put",
    url: String,
    body: String?,
    headers: Object,
}) => HttpResponse

docs.title: Http.defaultDesktopUserAgent
docs.text:
Returns the platform's web user-agent.

Signature
() => String

docs.title: Languages.isValid
docs.text:
Checks if the provided language code is valid.

Signature
(lang: String) => String

docs.title: Languages.all
docs.text:
Returns all the language codes.

Signature
() => List<String>

docs.title: TEnvironment.isDebug
docs.text:
Checks if the environment is debug.

Signature
() => Boolean

docs.title: Url
docs.text:
Represents a http response.

Property Signature Description authority String The authority. fragment String The fragment. host String The host. origin String The origin. path String The path. port Number The port. query String The query. scheme String The scheme. hasAbsolutePath String Is it an absolute path ? hasAuthority Boolean Does it have an authority? hasEmptyPath Boolean Does it have empty paths? hasFragment Boolean Does it have a fragment? hasPort Boolean Does it have a port? hasQuery Boolean Does it have a query? hasScheme Boolean Does it have a scheme? isAbsolute Boolean Is it an absolute path? pathSegments List<String> The path segments. queryParameters Object The query parameters.

docs.title: Url.parse
docs.text:
Parses an URL.

Signature
(url: String) => Url

docs.title: Url.ensureHttpScheme
docs.text:
Ensures http:// scheme.

Signature
(url: String) => String

docs.title: Url.ensureHttpsScheme
docs.text:
Ensures https:// scheme.

Signature
(url: String) => String

docs.title: Url.ensure
docs.text:
Ensures the url and transforms into a valid one.

Signature
(url: String) => String

docs.title: Url.encodeComponent
docs.text:
Encodes the component using percent-encoding (%).

Signature
(url: String) => String

docs.title: Url.decodeComponent
docs.text:
Decodes the component using percent-encoding (%).

Signature
(url: String) => String

docs.text:
Encodes the component using HTML 4.01 rules.

Signature
(url: String) => String

docs.title: Url.decodeQueryComponent

Signature
(url: String) => String

Signature
(queries: String) => Object

docs.title: Url.joinQueryString
docs.text:
Encodes the query string.

Signature
(queries: Object) => String

docs.title: Bulk Downloading
docs.text:
The episodes and chapters option supports selection in bulk.

Allowed Formats:

  • x,y,z - Multiple values which are comma-seperated.
  • x..y or x...y - From-to range.
  • x+y, x-y - Mathematical operation.

Available Variables:

  • first - First episode number.
  • last - Last episode number.

Valid Examples:

  • 1,2,3 - Selects episode 1, 2 and 3.
  • 1..3 or 1...3 - Selects 1, 2 and 3.
  • first..last or first...last - Selects all the episodes.
  • first..first+2 - Selects first 2 episodes.
  • last-2..last - Selects last 2 episodes.

docs.title: Argument Variables
docs.text: Options like destination, filename supports templates which will be replaced with actual values. For example, ${anime.name} will be replaced with the actual anime name. List of all the available templates can be checked here.

docs.title: JSON-mode
docs.text:
JSON mode can be used to obtain results in JSON format. Other applications can take advantage of this feature. This can be done using the global json flag.

yukimi tenka store --json

docs.title: Accepting usage policy
docs.text:
You must agree to the usage policy to use the application. This can be done using the agree-to-usage-policy command.

yukimi agree-to-usage-policy

docs.title: Use Terminal Mode
docs.text:
Use the terminal command to open a nested terminal. It is way faster than traditionally invoking the executable multiple times. This can be done using yukimi<path/to/executable> -t.

Do:

yukimi -t
> help
> tenka installed

Don't:

yukimi help
yukimi tenka installed

docs.title: Modules
docs.text: You must install modules to use the core commands within the application.

docs.title: Listing all modules
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> tenka store

docs.title: Installing a module
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> tenka install <module-name>
> tenka install hanime.tv readm.org

docs.title: Uninstalling a module
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> tenka uninstall <module-name>
> tenka uninstall hanime.tv

docs.title: Listing all installed modules
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> tenka installed

Note

Extensions are auto-updated upon restarting the application.

docs.title: Searching an anime
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> anime search <module-name> "<anime-name>"
> anime search hanime.tv "overflow season 1"

docs.title: Viewing an anime
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> anime info <module-name> "<anime-url>"
> anime info hanime.tv "https://hanime.tv/videos/hentai/overflow-season-1"

This lists all the information and episodes of the anime.

docs.title: Playing an anime
docs.text:
To play an anime, you must have mpv installed. The PATH environment variable should contain the path to mpv or it can be set in the application settings.

yukimi -t
> anime info hanime.tv "https://hanime.tv/videos/hentai/overflow-season-1" -e 1 -p

docs.title: Downloading an anime
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> anime info hanime.tv "https://hanime.tv/videos/hentai/overflow-season-1" -e 1 -d

Custom download path can be specified using the command options.

docs.title: Searching a manga
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> manga search <module-name> "<manga-name>"
> manga search mangadex.org "mayo chiki"

docs.title: Viewing a manga
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> manga info <module-name> "<manga-url>"
> manga info mangadex.org "https://api.mangadex.org/manga/afa0770f-4648-4c12-94c6-78cb96da3cb3"

This lists all the information and episodes of the anime.

docs.title: Reading a manga
docs.text:
When viewing a manga, it is locally downloaded into a temporary folder before opened. So, it is better to use the download option instead of read option.

yukimi -t
> manga info mangadex.org "https://api.mangadex.org/manga/afa0770f-4648-4c12-94c6-78cb96da3cb3" -c 1 -r

docs.title: Downloading a manga
docs.text:
yukimi -t
> manga info mangadex.org "https://api.mangadex.org/manga/afa0770f-4648-4c12-94c6-78cb96da3cb3" -c 1 -d

docs.title: Step 1: Download executable from releases
docs.text:
Download the pre-built binaries from releases.

  • For Windows: yukimi-windows.exe
  • For Linux: yukimi-linux
  • For MacOS: yukimi-macos

docs.title: Step 2: Rename it (Optional)
docs.text: Once you have downloaded the correct executable, go ahead and move it to an appropriate folder and rename it to just yukimi.exe (in Windows) or yukimi (in Linux and MacOS). You can also add it to your PATH environment variable if you want to access it from anywhere.

docs.title: Step 3: That's it
docs.text:
Now you can open the terminal in that folder and run yukimi help to get started.

Check out basic usage guide if you need help with using it.
